p: A study on the anticoccidial effect of M. lucida on Eimeria parasites has suggested its potential as an anticoccidial drug for veterinary purposes, especially the poultry birds [ 66]. Furthermore, the triterpenes and phytosterols derived from M. lucida showed high binding affinity toward the selected histone deacetylases (class I HDAC and HDAC7 isoforms) and exhibited good druggable characteristics [ 67].
